meanings.definition: Transfer or delegate (power or responsibility) to a lower level, especially from a central government to local authorities.
meanings.sent1: The mayor decided to devolve some decision-making to the city council.
meanings.sent2: It is common for countries to devolve certain powers to states or provinces.
meanings.sent3: The idea of letting the students choose the class pet might devolve into chaos.
meanings.sent4: As the project progressed, the team leader began to devolve more tasks to individual members.
meanings.sent5: The teacher's goal was to devolve more responsibility onto the students to foster independence.

meanings.definition: Pass down or be passed down from one generation to another.
meanings.sent1: Traditions and stories are often devolved from grandparents to grandchildren.
meanings.sent2: The antique clock was devolved to me by my great-grandmother.
meanings.sent3: The family heirloom was devolved through the generations, each adding their own story.
meanings.sent4: The values of hard work and honesty were devolved through the family lineage.
meanings.sent5: The ancient recipe was devolved through the ages, each cook adding a unique touch.

meanings.sent1: If left unattended, the old building will slowly devolve into a state of disrepair.
meanings.sent2: Neglect can cause a once vibrant neighborhood to devolve into a dangerous area.
meanings.sent3: The quality of the product started to devolve after the company changed ownership.
meanings.sent4: Without proper maintenance, the garden will devolve into a wild tangle of weeds.
meanings.sent5: Over time, the relationship between the two friends began to devolve into petty arguments.
